Description: JUUL agreed to pay $40 million to the state over the next six years for programs to prevent addiction to and study e-cigarettes in settlement of allegations the company deliberately marketing e-cigarettes to teens and misrepresented the potency and danger of nicotine in its products.

Attorney General Mark Brnovich announced a settlement with e-cigarette maker Juul Labs, Inc. that will require the company to pay $14.5 million and make significant changes to its corporate practices - ensuring JUUL products are not marketed or sold to youth in Arizona.
